Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Novel approaches to integrating color perception and color memory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Visual perception gives us information about objects in the world. For that information to be useful, however, it must be combined with memory. For example, the yellow color of a banana indicates ripeness only if it can be compared to a memory that distinguishes the yellow of ripe bananas from the green of unripe bananas. Everyday experience suggests that although sometimes color memory is very good (e.g. recalling the color of stop signs and bananas), it can also be very poor (e.g. picking out paint to match the walls at home). This everyday experience of color memory reflects a deep division between cognitive and perceptual scientists about the fidelity of color memory. How can these differences be reconciled? NSF-funded research conducted by Dr. Sarah Allred at Rutgers University aims to provide a single framework that unifies color perception and the disparate views of color memory. Human observers will make perceptual and memory judgments about the same colorful stimuli in progressively more complex environments. These data will then drive the development of a computational model that aims to describe color memory as a combination of color perception and independent noise. This view is in contrast to a prevailing account of cultural or linguistic relativity in color memory.

The relationship between perception and memory is important to fields as varied as forensic psychology (e.g. the reliability of eyewitness testimony), military reconnaissance, cognitive psychology (e.g. linguistic effects on memory) and medical diagnosis (e.g. does a dark cloud on an MRI image match memory templates of tumors?). The computational approach here represents an important advance to the study of perception and memory, because it will provide a baseline comparison for future research. This study will allow researchers to quantify how much of what is remembered is predicted by what was perceived. If memory is a predictable function of perception, there are two important implications: first, basic perceptual information will allow more sensible bounds to be placed on the reliability of memory; second, it suggests the possibility that querying memory in the appropriate perceptual environment will increase the reliability of memory. Although color is a relatively simple stimulus with which to probe the relationship between perception and memory, it is a good first approximation for more complicated stimuli like those involved in eyewitness testimony or medical diagnosis. This is because color is simple enough that its physical dimensions are well-characterized, thus making color amenable to computational modeling; in addition, unlike other simple physical stimuli such as oriented gratings, color is linked to higher order variables like emotion and language. Thus color provides a good bridge between simple physical stimuli and more complex stimuli with real-world applicability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using vision to guide behavior requires the interaction of visual perception and visual memory. For example, as you search to select the ripest tomato, you compare the perception of each tomato you see with your memory of previously seen tomatoes and your memory of ripe tomatoes. Despite their interaction, perception and memory are usually studied separately. In this grant, we made several novel discoveries by asking subjects to make a variety of perceptual and memory judgments about the colors of objects and then using this behavioral data to create predictive computational models.  

Over multiple experiments with real and computer-generated stimuli, we found that errors in memory are not random; instead, the pattern of errors shows bias in several predictable ways. First, memories are biased by the stimulus ensemble, or collection of things that observers see over the course of the experiment. Second, introducing sensory noise increases bias; in other words, the less certain your brain is about what you saw, the more biased your memory is likely to be. In these cases, memory is biased towards what the observer expects to be present. Third, memory errors are predicted by perceptual errors; stimuli that elicited large color-matching errors in memory also elicited errors when participants made color matches while looking back and forth between colors. This means that if we study memory without also studying perception, we might blame memory for errors that are better attributed to perception: our memory system could be faithfully reporting errors introduced by perceptual processing. Fourth, memory for colors tends to be biased by categories. Stimuli near the center of a category tend to me more accurately remembered than those near the borders of categories. 

The stimuli we used are very simple visual stimuli, but our results raise intriguing ideas about more complicated memories.  

In addition to the PI and a postdoctoral associate funded by the project, the research described here was conducted by nearly forty students in Camden, New Jersey, most of whom were undergraduates. Funds from this grant also allowed the full participation of students in several courses that converted from traditional lecture classes to digitally enhanced active learning classrooms. The students funded by this project were representative of the Rutgers-Camden student body, over 40% of whom identify as non-white, first-generation college students.  Through their dedicated lab work, these students learned scientific content and data skills.  They experienced the entire scientific process first-hand.  They were instrumental in the data collection process, and they co-authored presentations and traveled to conferences.  The benefits to these students’ intellectual and career development is an outcome of the project on equal footing with the specific intellectual findings and publications that resulted from the grant.
